To the Committee on Energy and Commerce,

I am writing to express my support for H.R. 7688, a bill to prohibit the importation of crude oil, petroleum, petroleum products, and liquefied natural gas from Venezuela and Iran.

The United States has a long history of opposing the regimes of Venezuela and Iran. These regimes are both authoritarian and repressive, and they have a history of human rights abuses. They are also both major exporters of oil and gas, and their exports have helped to prop up their economies.

The United States has a national interest in reducing its dependence on foreign oil and gas. This bill would help to achieve that goal by prohibiting the importation of oil and gas from Venezuela and Iran. It would also send a strong message to these regimes that the United States will not tolerate their support for terrorism and their repression of their own people.

I urge you to support H.R. 7688 and help to make it law.

Sincerely,

[Your Name]
s2986-118:
To prohibit the issuance of an interim or final rule, and to prohibit the inclusion in certain oil and gas leases, exploration or development plans, or well permits requirements or recommendations, that establish a vessel speed or operational restriction in the Central or Western Planning Area of the Gulf of Mexico of the outer Continental Shelf until the Secretary of the Interior and the Secretary of Commerce complete a study demonstrating that proposed mitigation efforts would have no negative impact on supply chains, United States offshore energy production and generation, military activities, including readiness, and United States commercial and recreational fishing maritime commerce, and for other purposes.

The undersigned, [your name], [your address], [your city, state, zip code], respectfully submit the following comments on [bill title].

We are writing to express our strong opposition to [bill title]. This bill would prohibit the issuance of an interim or final rule, and to prohibit the inclusion in certain oil and gas leases, exploration or development plans, or well permits requirements or recommendations, that establish a vessel speed or operational restriction in the Central or Western Planning Area of the Gulf of Mexico of the outer Continental Shelf until the Secretary of the Interior and the Secretary of Commerce complete a study demonstrating that proposed mitigation efforts would have no negative impact on supply chains, United States offshore energy production and generation, military activities, including readiness, and United States commercial and recreational fishing maritime commerce.

We believe that this bill is unnecessary and would have a negative impact on the economy of the Gulf Coast region. The Gulf of Mexico is a major source of oil and gas production for the United States, and a vessel speed or operational restriction would have a significant impact on the ability of companies to operate in this region. This would lead to higher costs for consumers and could put jobs at risk.

In addition, we believe that this bill would have a negative impact on the military. The Gulf of Mexico is a critical training area for the Navy and Marine Corps, and a vessel speed or operational restriction would make it more difficult for them to conduct training exercises. This could put our national security at risk.

Finally, we believe that this bill would have a negative impact on commercial and recreational fishing in the Gulf of Mexico. A vessel speed or operational restriction would make it more difficult for fishermen to operate in this region, and could lead to job losses.

For all of these reasons, we urge you to oppose [bill title].

Thank you for your time and consideration.

The U.S. House of Representatives is considering a bill that would provide whistleblower protections to certain workers in the offshore oil and gas industry. The bill, H.R. 2564, would create a new whistleblower protection program for employees of offshore oil and gas production facilities. The program would provide protection for employees who report violations of federal law, regulations, or contract requirements.

The bill is supported by a number of labor unions and environmental groups. They argue that the bill is necessary to protect workers from retaliation for reporting safety violations or other illegal activities.

The oil and gas industry opposes the bill. They argue that the bill would create a burdensome regulatory regime that would discourage investment in the offshore oil and gas industry.

The public is invited to submit comments on the bill. Comments can be submitted to the U.S. House of Representatives Committee on Natural Resources.

The following is a template for a public comment on the bill:

To: U.S. House of Representatives Committee on Natural Resources

From: [Your Name]

Re: H.R. 2564, the Offshore Worker Whistleblower Protection Act

I am writing to express my support for H.R. 2564, the Offshore Worker Whistleblower Protection Act. This bill would provide much-needed whistleblower protections for workers in the offshore oil and gas industry.

Whistleblowers play a vital role in protecting the public from unsafe and illegal activities. They often come forward with information about serious safety violations, environmental hazards, and other wrongdoing. However, whistleblowers often face retaliation from their employers for reporting these problems.

H.R. 2564 would provide whistleblowers with the protections they need to come forward with information about wrongdoing. The bill would create a new whistleblower protection program for employees of offshore oil and gas production facilities. The program would provide protection for employees who report violations of federal law, regulations, or contract requirements.

The bill would also provide whistleblowers with a number of other protections, including protection from retaliation, anti-retaliation counseling, and legal assistance.

I urge you to support H.R. 2564 and help to protect whistleblowers in the offshore oil and gas industry.

Sincerely,
[Your Name]

The insurance industry has a responsibility to help address climate change. By requiring insurance companies to disclose their investments and underwriting in the fossil fuel industry, this bill would help to shine a light on the industry's role in climate change and encourage it to take action to reduce its emissions.

I urge you to support this bill and help to make our communities safer from the impacts of climate change.

Sincerely,
[Your Name]

Dear [Name of Member of Congress],

I am writing to express my support for the bill to amend the Clean Air Act to eliminate the exemption for aggregation of emissions from oil and gas sources.

The Clean Air Act is one of the most important environmental laws in the United States, and it has been successful in reducing air pollution and improving public health. However, the exemption for aggregation of emissions from oil and gas sources has allowed these sources to avoid taking responsibility for their full emissions. This exemption has allowed oil and gas companies to pollute our air without facing the consequences.

The bill to eliminate the exemption for aggregation of emissions from oil and gas sources would close this loophole and ensure that these sources are held accountable for their pollution. This is an important step to protect public health and the environment.

I urge you to support this bill. Thank you for your time and consideration.

Sincerely,
[Your Name]

We support the goals of this bill, which are to discourage speculative oil and gas leasing and to promote enhanced multiple use management of public land and National Forest System land. We believe that these goals are important for the protection of our environment and for the sustainable use of our natural resources.

We are particularly concerned about the potential for speculative oil and gas leasing to harm the environment. We also support the goal of promoting enhanced multiple use management of public land and National Forest System land. We believe that these lands should be managed for a variety of uses, including recreation, conservation, and sustainable development. We believe that this bill will help to ensure that these lands are managed in a way that benefits all Americans.

We urge you to support this bill. Thank you for your time and consideration.

Dear [Name of Member of Congress],

I am writing to you today to express my support for the Methane Measurement and Research Act of 2023. This bill would direct the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) to conduct a measurement-based national methane research pilot study to quantify methane emissions from certain oil and gas infrastructure.

Methane is a potent greenhouse gas with a global warming potential 84 times greater than carbon dioxide over a 20-year period. Reducing methane emissions is essential to mitigating climate change.

The EPA's existing methane regulations have been successful in reducing methane emissions from new and modified sources of oil and gas infrastructure. However, these regulations do not cover existing sources of oil and gas infrastructure, which account for a significant portion of methane emissions.

The Methane Measurement and Research Act of 2023 would help to fill this gap by directing the EPA to conduct a measurement-based national methane research pilot study to quantify methane emissions from certain oil and gas infrastructure. This study would provide valuable information that could be used to develop more effective regulations to reduce methane emissions.

I urge you to support the Methane Measurement and Research Act of 2023. This bill is an important step towards reducing methane emissions and mitigating climate change.

Sincerely,
[Your Name]

Dear [Name of Member of Congress],

I am writing to you today to express my support for the bill to reinstate the ban on the export of crude oil and natural gas produced in the United States.

I believe that this bill is in the best interests of the United States for a number of reasons. First, it will help to reduce the cost of energy for American consumers. By keeping crude oil and natural gas in the United States, we will be able to meet our own energy needs and avoid having to import these products from foreign countries. This will put downward pressure on prices and make it more affordable for American families to heat their homes and fuel their cars.

Second, the bill will help to create jobs in the United States. The oil and gas industry is a major employer in our country, and by keeping these products in the United States, we will be able to support these jobs and help to grow our economy.

Third, the bill will help to reduce our dependence on foreign oil. By reducing our reliance on imports, we will be less vulnerable to supply disruptions and price shocks from unstable regions of the world. This will make our country more secure and prosperous.

I urge you to support this bill and help to protect the interests of the United States.

Sincerely,
[Your Name]
s1707-118:
To the Committee on Energy and Commerce,

I am writing to express my support for H.R. 6459, a bill to amend the Energy Policy and Conservation Act to reinstate the ban on the export of crude oil and natural gas produced in the United States.

I believe that reinstating the ban on the export of crude oil and natural gas produced in the United States is in the best interests of our country. The export of these vital resources has led to higher prices for consumers, while doing little to benefit the economy. In fact, a recent study by the Center for Economic and Policy Research found that the export of crude oil and natural gas has cost the United States economy more than $100 billion since 2015.

In addition, the export of these resources has made the United States more vulnerable to global energy shocks. When oil prices spike, as they did in 2018, the United States is more likely to be affected because we are now a net exporter of oil. This makes it more difficult for our economy to weather these shocks.

I urge you to support H.R. 6459 and reinstate the ban on the export of crude oil and natural gas produced in the United States.

Thank you for your time and consideration.

Sincerely,

[Your Name]
